Dear Elizabeth Lord:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
10/13-10/17/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement specifications consistent with the
information contained in the reevaluation. The placement specifications must
include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic background, and
characteristics of children preferred by the applicants.
Four of Six files of open foster homes reviewed contained reevaluation reports that
did not identify the family's preference related to the SOGIE of youths placed in the
home.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing agency to another
child placing agency, a modified service plan must be completed within 30
calendar days of the change in agency responsibility if no other plan is done
within 30 days. The plan must address why the agency responsibility
changed and whether there are any modifications to existing service plans.
Two of Eight open files of youths in foster care placements reviewed did not contain
modified service plans documenting the reason for agency change and any changes
to services written within 30 days of case transfer.
2

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents and the foster
parents in the development of service plans to enable the parent or parents
and foster parents to understand the plan for the child and the parents' and
the foster parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying out the plan. An
agency shall give a copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan with
the parent or parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent
or parents and foster parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the child and the child's family
is confidential.
Two of Eight open files of youth in foster care placements reviewed did not contain
documentation of all PATPs being provided to/discussed with parents/caregivers.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
• (2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child, and the foster
parent, if applicable, in the child's placement at least once every month.
One of Eight open files of youths in foster care placements contained social work
contacts documenting the foster parent was not present for all monthly foster home
visits with the youth.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Licensing rules require workers/supervisors to receive 16 hours of orientation
after initial appointment and before assumption of assigned duties. The topics
that must be covered during orientation are outlined in the same rule. Many of
these are agency specific. For any caseload carrying staff, the orientation hours
must be completed prior to receiving a caseload, as that would be the
assumption of their assigned duties.
• When completing SER's in CWLM ensure the correct boxes are checked and the
correct dates are entered regarding the verbal summary of findings.
• When documenting family's SOGIE preferences in adoption and foster home
family reports, ensure you are being specific and addressing all aspects of
SOGIE (Sexual Orientation, Gender Identity and Expression.)
Examples : Open to youth who identify with any sexual orientation. Are not open
to youth who identify as transgender or non-binary. Not open to any SOGIE other
than heterosexual youths who identify as the gender they were assigned at
birth/cisgender. Only open to youth who identify as gay, lesbian, or heterosexual.
Open to any gender identity and gender expression. Open to youths of any
SOGIE.
• In report section regarding pets in the home, be sure to document the worker's
assessment based on their observations/interactions to ensure safety. One
report reviewed documented the foster parent reported the dogs were friendly.
The only assessment made by the worker was that the dogs bark loudly upon her
arrival. Another report reviewed stated the dogs "are very overprotective of the
children." This statement should be clarified as this has a negative implication.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• When onboarding staff utilize a consistent method of documenting orientation
hours and topics.
5

• If caregivers or youths are not cooperative with home visit and or documentation
requirements, workers must document their efforts. For example, if a family
consistently refuses to check the applicable boxes and sign a PATP indicating
they have received and reviewed the plan, the worker must document in SWC
how the PATP was provided and when/how the PATP was reviewed with the
family. A family/youth's consistent failure to comply does not negate the need for
consistent, thorough documentation.
• During monthly supervision with staff and during service plan reviews,
supervisors should be reviewing case contacts to ensure workers are
documenting face to face meetings with youths and caregivers in the caregiver's
home as well as document quality contacts. Some contacts reviewed did not
have all participants added to the contact and did not have enough narrative to
determine who was present. Multiple contacts reviewed would not meet quality
contact standards required by MDHHS policy.
• The majority of PATPs reviewed with caregiver and/or parent signatures were not
signed by the worker and supervisor. When asking someone to sign a legal
document, the document should be the current approved and signed document.
This is verified by the worker and supervisor signing prior to the other
participants. Generating and signing the case service plans and PATPs at the
time of approval would negate the need to collect the signatures later.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The one special evaluation report, dated 1/30/2025, in which a
noncompliance related to corporal punishment was established was reviewed.
Based on coordination with MDHHS and consultation with DCWL, the agency's
recommendation of a CAP was appropriate.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The first
CAP was submitted in response to the 10/29/2024 licensing renewal inspection
report. That CAP was approved on 11/20/2024 and addressed four violation; one
related to personnel records in which two of fourteen files were found in violation
of timely completion of criminal history checks, one related to face to face visits
with youth and caregivers in the caregivers home located in one of eight files
reviewed, one related to independent living contracts being updated and signed
every 90 days located in three of eight files reviewed, and one related to adoption
family assessments being completed timely located in one of six files reviewed.
The CAP was monitored for six months during which CAP compliance was
determined. The agency has demonstrated that CAP was effective overall as only
6

one violation addressed in that CAP was repeated during this year’s inspection.
This year, ten violations were established which have not been established in the
past two years. Five of those violations were located in one closed independent
living youth file, two were located in one open independent living youth file, two
were located in two open foster care files, and the remaining violations were found
in four open foster home files. The significant increase in number of violations this
year is, in part, attributed to one rule violation including five subsection violations.
No pervasive patterns of violations were identified.
The second CAP was submitted in response to licensing special investigation
report 2024SIC0001511 dated 8/30/24. The CAP was approved on 11/1/2024 and
addressed a violation of licensing rule 400.12325(1). The CAP was monitored for
a six-month period during which it was determined the agency was in compliance
with all action steps identified.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment dated 10/1/2025 was reviewed and discussed
during the entrance meeting. The chief administrator identified several actions the
agency took to improve new staff training and support. The agency experienced a
period of full staffing and stability; however, recently, they have experienced foster
care worker turnover. Some of the staff turnover was related to staff self-
identifying inability to perform the requirements of the job while others were related
to poor performance identified by leadership.
Financial Overview
The agency's financial audit for the year ending on December 31, 2024, was
reviewed. No financial concerns were identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff members interviewed all reported it has been somewhat hectic as of late
due to staffing turnover and caseload shifts. They all reported getting good support
from direct supervisors, the program manager, and the agency director. They
indicated the agency has kept new worker caseloads at 11, which is helpful as
they learn the job. No concerns were reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has adequate space and equipment to provide the delivery of foster
care, independent living, and certification services. Physical CHRI is stored
securely within a dedicated locked cabinet, and a cross shredder is located next to
the physical CHRI. All other foster care, independent living, foster home, and open
adoption files are stored securely in a file storage room. Closed adoption files are
stored in a separate locked cabinet in an area separate from all other files to
prevent unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns were identified.
7

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
